awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Building a Global Community to Crowdsource-Clean the Planet
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project focuses on litter - one of the world's most pervasive and toxic problems. To many, it's dirty, disgusting, and someone else's problem to solve. Unfortunately, we all suffer the consequences, as litter impacts our economy, degrades the environment, demoralizes community pride, kills wildlife, and poisons the food system. This project builds on the accomplishments of an SBIR Phase I project that developed a mobile technology empowering anyone to identify, map, and collect the world's litter, while simultaneously connecting to a broader community of associated brands, cities, schools. 


The company has integrated image recognition and machine learning algorithms into its software to advance the crowdsourcing of litter data and cleanup activities. This advancement will allow for the identification of litter even if the item is in a deep state of decay and decomposition. This project also aims to continue building the Global Database of Litter, a technology platform that integrates the company's litter taxonomic classification with other data sets including location, time, retail locations, and the watershed. This data provides great potential to improve municipal infrastructure, resource allocation, brand packaging redesign, and individual responsibility that promotes positive behavioral change. Like the National Science Foundation, this project aims to promote the progress of science and advance our national health, prosperity, and welfare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Litterati is on a mission to eradicate litter. What started with one person picking up a single cigarette, has grown into a community of ~300,000 using a mobile application to identify, map, and collect 20M+ pieces of litter in 185 countries. The resulting Global Litter Database is used to inform policy, influence packaging, and inspire personal responsibility. 

Since being awarded a Phase I grant, Litterati's data set increased ten-fold, while the community tripled in size. The company designed and developed litter studies in 60 cities worldwide and conducted a national litter baseline in the United Kingdom. 

The Phase II grant amplified the technological and commercial impact of the platform. Funding supported an image ingestion pipeline allowing millions of images to be processed from the community and scientific researchers, plus the creation of computer vision models that identify objects, materials, and brands. These models are trained on litter, various environmental conditionals, and specific geographies.

Another key area of development was the process design to train, certify, and manage researchers. Since the company?s initial research project, conducted in Wake County, NC in 2019, Litterati has trained 500+ researchers throughout 40 countries. The company then developed a standard protocol and common approach for data collection, allowing for geographic diversity. By 2021, Litterati had published its first Litter Index, comparing the amount of litter per meter (LPM) across 49 cities. Results indicated an average of 0.64 pieces LPM, with smoking and food/drink packaging as the items most often found. 

Litterati also launched an Open Data Platform allowing scientists, educators, government officials, and circular economy specialists to access community-generated data. Individuals and organizations have gone on to create municipal heat maps, monitor specific areas, even publish articles about the impact of COVID on litter types and rates. 

These NSF-backed developments has allowed Litterati to perform litter research consistently, and at scale, leading to the 2022 ?City Fingerprint? project; a multi-city, year long study across Hayward, CA, Memphis TN, and Norfolk VA. Each City Fingerprint began with a city-wide baseline analysis, with research carried out in 300 locations per city. The granular style of data established the what, where, and when of each city?s litter, and was then followed with seasonal measurements to understand how litter changed over time. 

Each phase pinpointed the areas of highest litter concentration, and the associated objects, materials, and brands, thus presenting the three cities with the insights necessary to prioritize their efforts, and measure which interventions provide the greatest environmental impact and return on investment. 

From New York to Nairobi, litter can be found everywhere. In order to solve this pandemic, we must have an effective measurement system. The combination of Litterati?s mobile applications, computer vision models, scientific protocols, annotation schemes, and ever growing data, creates awareness and transparency, ultimately leading to changes in policy, packaging, and personal responsibility.
